messageBody:
On 26/02/2008, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains762@...> wrote:
> It's only my opinion, but what I observe teams writing some end-to-end
> tests, but not nearly enough, and finding some integration defects,
> but not nearly enough.

That certainly tallies with my experience.

> I believe that the less we rely on end-to-end tests, the less we'd
> allow ourselves to duplicate high-level structures, and therefore the
> fewer integration defects we'd have. This would make end-to-end tests
> all the less valuable.

I've found the opposite. Many times I've seen teams do "TDD" but only
write unit tests. They had integration problems that were only
brought under control when they started writing end-to-end tests.

The most alarming I've seen was a team that used FIT to drive their
business objects, not drive the app end-to-end. The business signed
off functionality based on the FIT tests but I found that the main
method contained nothing but one comment: "TODO write this"! Of
course, that's a process breakdown not a technical problem, but an
entertaining scare-story nonetheless in a Daily WTF kind of way.

--Nat
